title: Boeing, Airbus, Embraer eye APAC's aviation boom amid production struggles - AeroTime
description:
Boeing, Airbus, and Embraer each laid out ambitious plans for what’s shaping up to be aviation’s most dramatic growth story over the next two decades.
The numbers being discussed speak of staggering growth in the Asia Pacific (APAC) region: tens of thousands of new aircraft needed, trillions in economic value, and growth rates that dwarf every other region.
Recently, new orders have been secured from ANA (18 aircraft), Malaysia Airlines (60), and Japan Airlines (50).
Stanley emphasized sustainability as a key differentiator, noting that new Airbus aircraft deliver 25% better fuel efficiency, with the company working toward 100% sustainable aviation fuel capability.
“Asia Pacific is not by coincidence a focus market,” Meijer emphasized.
text:
At the Association of Asia Pacific Airlines’ 69th Assembly of Presidents in Bangkok held November 14-16, 2025, leading aircraft manufacturers presented their forecasts for what they’re calling the industry’s biggest growth opportunity in years.

Boeing, Airbus, and Embraer each laid out ambitious plans for what’s shaping up to be aviation’s most dramatic growth story over the next two decades.

The numbers being discussed speak of staggering growth in the Asia Pacific (APAC) region: tens of thousands of new aircraft needed, trillions in economic value, and growth rates that dwarf every other region.

However, the manufacturers presenting these rosy forecasts are the same ones currently running months or even years behind on deliveries. Adding tens of thousands of orders to already stretched production lines won’t make things any easier.

Boeing: Banking on Southeast Asia’s 7% growth

Dave Schulte, Boeing’s Managing Director for APAC Marketing, emphasized Southeast Asia’s massive potential, reckoning that the region needs 4,885 new aircraft over the next 20 years, split between 3,975 single-aisle jets and 910 widebodies.

“We’re forecasting 7% annual growth—the fastest in the world alongside South Asia,” Schulte explained, noting that the region’s middle class has doubled over 25 years and currently shows no signs of slowing.

But Boeing faces a challenge it readily admits: a global shortfall of 1,500 aircraft that should already have been delivered, but weren’t. “Airlines used to plan five or six years out. Now they have to plan 10, even 15 years into the future,” Schulte observed, highlighting how the supply crunch is reshaping the industry.

The company is betting on its 737 MAX family, claiming that one takes off or lands every 12-13 seconds globally. Recently, new orders have been secured from ANA (18 aircraft), Malaysia Airlines (60), and Japan Airlines (50).

Airbus: betting on APAC’s billion-strong middle class

Airbus President APAC Anand Stanley presented even larger numbers, forecasting nearly 20,000 new passenger aircraft needed across the broader Asia-Pacific region, representing 46% of global demand.

“All of this ends up making Asia Pacific one of the most successful commercial and economic stories, one of the largest consumer markets in the world,” Stanley stated, pointing to GDP growth of 3.4% annually and an expanding middle class of one billion people.

The European manufacturer projects demand for 16,000 single-aisle aircraft and 3,480 widebodies, with the region already operating the world’s largest widebody fleet at 900 units.

Stanley emphasized sustainability as a key differentiator, noting that new Airbus aircraft deliver 25% better fuel efficiency, with the company working toward 100% sustainable aviation fuel capability.

Recent wins include Qantas’s A350-1000 for Project Sunrise, the world’s longest commercial flights, plus new Asian customers such as EVA Air and Korean Air joining the A350 program.

Embraer: building a $10 billion business in the APAC regional market

While Boeing and Airbus battle over large jet orders, Embraer CEO Arjan Meijer sees massive opportunity in the regional segment. The Brazilian manufacturer forecasts APAC and China will need 3,390 aircraft in the up-to-150-seat category, the largest regional requirement globally.

“We hope to climb to a $10 billion company towards the end of the decade,” Meijer revealed, in light of a $50.2 billion commercial backlog.

Embraer’s strategy targets three specific opportunities: penetrating cost-conscious low-cost carriers with the E195-E2’s improved economics; replacing Asia’s 800 aging turboprops (37% of the global fleet); and expanding hub connectivity for major carriers. The company has already notched up wins with Virgin Australia, All Nippon Airways, and LATAM, pushing E2 commitments beyond 250 aircraft.

Unlike its larger rivals, Embraer is building ground-up infrastructure, establishing simulators in Singapore, plus warehouses with $100 million in parts, and strategic partnerships across the region. “Asia Pacific is not by coincidence a focus market,” Meijer emphasized.

Reality check: orders don’t fly, aircraft do

All three aircraft manufacturers are essentially betting their futures on the same forecast: Asia-Pacific is where industry action will be for the next 20 years.

However, the companies are already behind. Boeing admits they’re 1,500 aircraft short of where they should be, airlines are scrambling to lock in slots a decade out, and supply chain issues remain in place.

title: EU and UAE Strengthen Partnership to Boost Sustainable Aviation Fuels - Arab CIOLook
description:
Prime Highlights: The EU and UAE have strengthened cooperation to advance sustainable aviation fuels and support greener air travel.
Key Facts: The EU’s aviation regulation requires airlines to use 2% sustainable aviation fuel by 2025, increasing to 70% by 2050.
Background: The EU and UAE stepped up their cooperation to reduce aviation emissions by holding a session on sustainable aviation fuels at the Dubai Airshow 2025.
The summit saw the participation of officials and industry experts in the discussion of how sustainable aviation fuels could be used and produced more.
The meeting also noted ICAO’s goal to cut global aviation emissions by 5% by 2030 through the use of sustainable fuels.
text:
Prime Highlights:

The EU and UAE have strengthened cooperation to advance sustainable aviation fuels and support greener air travel.

Both sides emphasized working together globally to help the aviation sector meet long-term climate goals.

Key Facts:

The EU’s aviation regulation requires airlines to use 2% sustainable aviation fuel by 2025, increasing to 70% by 2050.

The UAE is progressing under its Net Zero 2050 and National Hydrogen strategies to expand clean fuel production and use.

Background:

The EU and UAE stepped up their cooperation to reduce aviation emissions by holding a session on sustainable aviation fuels at the Dubai Airshow 2025.

The session was hosted by the EU Delegation in the UAE as part of the EU Green Diplomacy Weeks, and was held in cooperation with the UAE Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure and the EU-GCC Green Transition Project.

The summit saw the participation of officials and industry experts in the discussion of how sustainable aviation fuels could be used and produced more.

The EU mandates airlines to consume a minimum of 2 percent sustainable aviation fuel by 2025, with the percentage increasing to 70 percent by 2050. The UAE presented its developments within its Net Zero 2050 and National Hydrogen plans, which focus on increasing the application of clean fuels in the nation. The meeting also noted ICAO’s goal to cut global aviation emissions by 5% by 2030 through the use of sustainable fuels.

H.E. Lucie Berger, Ambassador of the European Union to the UAE, said that stronger cooperation was essential to unlocking innovation and advancing fuel production at scale. She noted that shared ambitions could drive the industry toward climate neutrality.

H.E. Eng Saif Ghubash, Assistant Undersecretary at the Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure, said the UAE aims to boost local production of sustainable aviation fuels and introduce stronger policies to support the move toward cleaner air travel.

The session is part of the EU-GCC Cooperation on Green Transition Project, which works to strengthen regional partnerships in clean energy, sustainability, and financing to support global net-zero goals.

title: DHL Express and Phillips 66 advance Sustainable Aviation Fuel usage in the U.S. through ...
description:
DHL Express announced a significant Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) agreement with Phillips 66, a leading integrated downstream energy provider and SAF producer headquartered in the United States.
Utilizing a book-and-claim approach, DHL Express is able to manage its carbon footprint through the use of sustainable fuels in the aviation sector.
Travis Cobb, EVP Global Operations and Aviation at DHL Express, stated: “This agreement with Phillips 66 is a significant milestone for DHL Express as we work towards our sustainability goals.
DHL Express has a long-standing commitment to sustainability, and this deal aligns with its broader strategy to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
Through innovative solutions like this, DHL Express continues to lead the logistics industry in addressing climate change while providing reliable and efficient services to its customers.
text:
DHL Express announced a significant Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) agreement with Phillips 66, a leading integrated downstream energy provider and SAF producer headquartered in the United States. This agreement will see the delivery of over 240,000 metric tons of SAF over three years, aimed at reducing lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions by approximately 737,000 metric tons compared to conventional jet fuel, marking a major milestone in DHL's commitment to sustainability.

The majority of the SAF will be delivered to Los Angeles International Airport (LAX), DHL’s U.S. West Coast Gateway, with future intended deliveries to other West Coast airports where DHL maintains operations, such as San Francisco International Airport (SFO). Utilizing a book-and-claim approach, DHL Express is able to manage its carbon footprint through the use of sustainable fuels in the aviation sector. The SAF will be produced at Phillips 66’s Rodeo Renewable Energy Complex in California, one of the world’s largest renewable fuels facilities with a production capacity of 150 million gallons per year of neat SAF (i.e., SAF that is not blended with conventional jet fuel).

Travis Cobb, EVP Global Operations and Aviation at DHL Express, stated: “This agreement with Phillips 66 is a significant milestone for DHL Express as we work towards our sustainability goals. By securing a reliable supply of SAF, we are not only reducing our carbon emissions – and those within our customers’ supply chains – but also setting a precedent for the logistics and air cargo industries in the U.S. Our collaboration with Phillips 66 underscores our commitment to a lower-carbon future and demonstrates the importance of sustainable practices in our operations.”

Brian Mandell, EVP Marketing and Commercial at Phillips 66, stated: “This agreement between Phillips 66 and DHL demonstrates our shared commitment to SAF market leadership and credible action in the growing SAF industry. Through our global renewable fuel business, we are committed to supporting DHL and our customers in achieving their decarbonization goals. Our agreement with DHL showcases cross-industry collaboration, and together, we aim to drive progress toward sustainable solutions in the aviation sector.”

The agreement with Phillips 66 represents one of the largest SAF deals by a U.S. producer and for the overall air cargo sector, paving the way for future collaborations in the SAF space. DHL Express has a long-standing commitment to sustainability, and this deal aligns with its broader strategy to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

DHL Express has been actively securing SAF partnerships worldwide including in Europe, America, and the Asia Pacific regions since 2021, and this new agreement exemplifies its dedication to leveraging sustainable aviation fuels to address its air freight carbon footprint effectively. This agreement will contribute significantly to DHL's GoGreen Plus service, which enables customers to reduce their Scope 3 greenhouse gas emissions using SAF. Through innovative solutions like this, DHL Express continues to lead the logistics industry in addressing climate change while providing reliable and efficient services to its customers.

title: Global food transportation decarbonization through wastes-derived biofuels based on a ... - Nature
description:
A study based on “food miles” concept revealed that, when considering the entire food supply chain, emissions from food transportation account for ~19% of global food system emissions2.
This underscores the critical need for strategies aimed at mitigating emissions associated with food transportation, contributing co-benefits in decarbonizing both food system and transportation system.
To address these gaps, this study establishes an internal recycling loop within the food system where food system waste streams are repurposed for food transportation.
1, the food system spans five sequential stages: agricultural production, food transportation and trade, processing and transformation, retail and provisioning, and food consumption.
On this basis, this study proposes an internal recycling loop within the food system, whereby food system wastes are repurposed for food transportation applications.
text:
The food system, as a key component of human economic activity, is responsible for approximately one-third of global anthropogenic greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions1. Food transportation bridges food and transportation systems. A study based on “food miles” concept revealed that, when considering the entire food supply chain, emissions from food transportation account for ~19% of global food system emissions2. This underscores the critical need for strategies aimed at mitigating emissions associated with food transportation, contributing co-benefits in decarbonizing both food system and transportation system.

With global population growth and an increasing demand for food, the amount of wastes generated by food system has risen sharply. Proper management of food system wastes has thus become a crucial aspect of controlling or mitigating emissions within food system3,4,5,6,7. The conversion of food system wastes into biofuels for transportation has already seen widespread application. Among food system wastes, used cooking oil (UCO) and crop residues (CRs) demonstrate advantages in collection and treatment efficiency, exhibiting more homogeneous compositions compared with other wastes such as kitchen waste. Additionally, the technologies for their conversion into biofuels are more mature, establishing them as primary feedstocks for biofuel production8,9,10,11. Biodiesel is the most common form of biofuels, primarily used in road, railway & inland waterway, and marine transportation12,13,14.

Established pathways for converting UCO include esterification-hydrogenation and Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids (HEFA) processes following hydrolysis15,16. Esterification-hydrogenation yields high-quality biodiesel suitable for road, rail, and inland waterway transport by effectively converting UCO fatty acids. HEFA technology, involving high-pressure hydrogenation, transforms UCO lipids into drop-in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), currently the dominant bio-aviation pathway, achieving higher energy density and combustion performance17,18,19,20. CRs can be converted via fast pyrolysis or gasification-Fischer-Tropsch synthesis21,22. Fast pyrolysis rapidly decomposes solid biomass into liquid bio-oil, while Fischer-Tropsch synthesis produces premium liquid fuels from syngas without requiring specific feedstock chemical structures, making it suitable for producing Fischer-Tropsch aviation fuel from lignocellulosic materials like CRs17,18,19,20. Life cycle assessment (LCA) is widely employed to compare different fuel technologies, with numerous studies demonstrating that biofuels, when replacing fossil fuels, result in significant emission reduction23,24,25. Regarding the collection and energy potential of CRs and UCO, a large number of research has estimated the amount of CRs available in different regions based on crop yields and residue indices26,27,28,29. When estimating the energy potential of CRs, it is crucial to account for competing uses beyond biofuel production30,31. Contextualized in the diverse ways of CRs utilization, and the influence of climate and dietary habits on their spatial distribution, extant research has conducted analysis of CRs’ competing uses targeting typical countries or regions32,33,34. Studies on UCO recycling predominantly address collection and transportation strategies at the consumption end35,36. Unlike CRs, which have multiple competing uses, the main energy utilization pathway for UCO is biodiesel production34,35,36,37. Various conversion technologies have been examined to explore UCO’s potential for biofuel production38,39,40,41.

Building on studies of food system wastes’ energy potentials, some research has also analyzed the emission reduction benefits of biofuel production from food system wastes in specific regions. Typical studies cover estimates of the emission reduction potential of biodiesel produced from CRs in Europe for use in marine transportation42, assessment of the bioenergy potential and emission reduction contributed by CRs utilization in China43, analysis of the environmental impacts of converting UCO to biodiesel in China44, and evaluation of the emission reduction effect of biodiesel produced from UCO in Iran under specific UCO recycling strategies45. These studies further demonstrate the potential of utilizing wastes-derived biofuels for controlling transportation emissions in practical applications.

While converting food system wastes to biofuels has demonstrated effectiveness in fossil fuel substitution and emission reduction, critical knowledge gaps remain. First, from a food system perspective, the energy and environmental benefits feedback achievable by repurposing such biofuels specifically for food transportation remains unclear. Second, existing research lacks an integrated analytical framework that concurrently addresses global variations in food system wastes availability and disparate food transportation fuel demands across countries. Consequently, the extent to which domestically produced biofuels can offset heterogeneous transportation fossil fuel demands remains unknown, hindering the characterization of individual countries’ contributions to decarbonizing global food and transportation systems.

To address these gaps, this study establishes an internal recycling loop within the food system where food system waste streams are repurposed for food transportation. It aims to quantify national-level biofuel production potentials from such wastes and evaluate the corresponding contribution in decarbonizing food system transportation by substituting fossil fuels. The internal recycling loop within food system is illustrated in Fig. 1, the food system spans five sequential stages: agricultural production, food transportation and trade, processing and transformation, retail and provisioning, and food consumption. UCO and CRs generated from these stages are collected and processed into biofuels. These biofuels then substitute fossil fuels across various transportation modes (road, railway & inland waterway, marine, aviation), providing energy for food transportation while reducing emissions within the food system. Though biofuel utilization may extend beyond food-related transportation in practice, emerging carbon trading mechanisms and global carbon market developments enable the reallocation of environmental benefits to food systems through carbon quota allocations or fiscal incentives46,47. This approach creates synergistic feedback between emission reductions in the transportation sector and sustainability improvements in food production chains.

From the food system internal loop perspective, targeting 130 countries in the world, the availability and biofuel production potentials of CRs and UCO in various countries are accounted, combined with examining country-specific fossil fuel demands of food transportation adopting multiregional input-output model (MRIO). On this basis, four scenarios are designed to analyze the biofuel production and emission reduction contributions under varying food system wastes utilization levels (scenario of sole UCO utilization, scenario of sole CRs utilization, scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization, and scenario of maximum biofuel production potential). The life cycle analysis and GREET (greenhouse gases, regulated emissions, and energy use in transportation) model are combined to compare the well-to-wheel/haul/wake (WTW/WTH/WTWa) emissions from typical biofuels and fossil fuels under the four scenarios, including emissions from the production phase (well-to-pump, WTP) and the operation phase (pump-to-wheel/haul/wake, PTW/PTH/PTWa). The findings are expected to provide references for informing global energy utilization strategies of food system wastes, and sustainability of food transportation.

Fossil fuel demand of global food transportation

Analysis of this study reveals that the aggregate food transportation fossil fuel demand across 130 countries amounts to around 3.0 EJ (1 EJ = 1018 J), constituting 3.3% of total transportation fossil fuel demand. Figure 2 illustrates the distribution of food transportation fossil fuel demands across various transportation modes. As one of the world’s preeminent food producers and consumers, China exhibits substantially higher food transportation fossil fuel demand compared with other countries. Similarly, other major food-producing countries, including India, Brazil, the United States, and Russia, demonstrate elevated demand, while the African and Middle Eastern countries show comparatively lower demand. Among four transportation modes, road transportation dominates the fossil fuel demand, accounting for ~80.6% of total demand across 130 countries. Aviation and marine transport follow with 8.4% and 7.4% respectively. Railway & inland waterway transportation exhibits significantly lower fossil fuel dependence (3.6% combined), primarily due to the higher electrification levels of railway. Regionally, railway & inland waterway fuel demands are concentrated in China, Latin America, and the Middle East, with China and Russia recording elevated shares of 8.86% and 6.25% respectively. Notably, archipelagic and coastal countries like the Philippines, Brunei, and Indonesia demonstrate exceptional marine fossil fuel intensity, with marine transportation constituting over 20% of their national fossil fuel consumption.

Biofuel production from food system wastes

This study suggests that the theoretically maximum biofuel production from UCO across 130 countries reaches 0.41 EJ (1.03%), while CRs-derived biofuels exhibit an overwhelmingly higher potential of 38.77 EJ (98.97%). This disparity arises because CRs possess inherent advantages in sheer amount, being inevitable agricultural byproducts with broad geographical distribution. While UCO, despite its higher conversion efficiency, is constrained by limited waste oil availability and immature collection infrastructure. These limitations collectively restrict UCO’s total biofuel production potential far below that of CRs. Figure 3 delineates the biofuel production from UCO and CRs across countries, revealing that those with higher food production and consumption demonstrate correspondingly greater potentials. Regionally, for UCO-derived biofuel production, China (106.8 PJ, 1 PJ = 1015 J) and the United States (100.0 PJ) collectively contribute 51.0% of the global total, driven by their extensive food service industries and consumption patterns. Major oilseed-producing countries, including Indonesia (32.6 PJ), Malaysia (29.5 PJ), and India (15.8 PJ), form the secondary tier, contributing 19.2% of the global total and correlating with their expanding vegetable oil utilization in food processing sectors. For CRs-derived biofuel production, major agricultural countries demonstrate overwhelming advantages: China (10.7 EJ), the United States (8.2 EJ), India (7.6 EJ), and Brazil (6.4 EJ) collectively account for 55.2% of the total, supported by vast croplands and high-intensity farming systems. Other leading grain producers such as Russia and Argentina follow, with CRs-derived biofuel production surpassing 2 EJ.

The biofuel production from UCO and CRs varies significantly depending on their utilization rate (especially competing uses for CRs) and energy conversion efficiency. UCO demonstrates superior energy conversion efficiency compared with CRs (Table S5 in Supplementary Information), yielding higher biofuel production per unit of wastes (PJ). Figure 4 presents a comparative result between fossil fuel demand and biofuel production from UCO and CRs across 11 regions (divided according to World Oil Outlook from OPEC48, with clustering of countries by economic parity and geographic proximity) under four scenarios. Table S8 provides detailed country-specific data regarding the fossil fuel demand that could be satisfied by UCO and CRs-derived biofuels. In the scenario of sole UCO utilization, significant biofuel production is seen in Asia, OECD Americas, and Europe. In the scenario of sole CRs utilization, despite a 7% utilization limit, CRs show broader potential, with over a third of 130 countries fully covering their food transportation fossil fuel demand. This performance confirms CRs’ persistently superior biofuel production capacity relative to UCO, attributable to their fundamental advantage in sheer production amount. The scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization outperforms sole-feedstock scenarios, meeting most food transportation fossil fuel demand except in the Middle East and Russia. In the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, the biofuel production exceeds food transportation fossil fuel demand in most regions, with India and Latin America capable of meeting their entire transportation sector’s fossil fuel demand (Fig. S2).

Emission reductions in food transportation through food system wastes-derived biofuels

Total emissions from the production and use of fossil fuels in food transportation across 130 countries are 256.6 million metric tonnes (Mt) CO2. Figure 5 shows emission distributions across four transportation modes in 11 regions. Road transportation dominates the total emissions, contributing 204.7 Mt CO₂ (80.7% of emissions across four modes), followed by aviation and marine transportation with tied contributions (19.8 Mt CO₂, 7.8%). Railway & inland waterway transportation exhibits the lowest emissions at 9.2 Mt CO₂, accounting for only 3.7%. Regionally, China exhibits the highest emissions across all modes except marine transportation, with road transportation (48.5 Mt CO₂, 23.7% of global road transportation emissions) and railway & inland waterway transportation (4.9 Mt CO₂, 53.5% of global railway & inland waterway transportation emissions) being particularly significant. Other Asian regions, the Middle East, and Latin America collectively account for around half of marine transportation emissions, each exceeding 25 Mt CO₂. In aviation transportation, OECD European countries (31.95 Mt CO₂, 16.12% of global aviation transportation emissions) emerge as major contributors alongside China.

Each country exhibits distinct emission reduction profiles in food transportation by utilizing food system wastes-derived biofuels. Figure 6a–d illustrates country-specific emission reductions across scenarios, with details for 130 countries presented in Table S9. The scenario of sole UCO utilization achieves 28.9 Mt CO₂ reductions (11.4% of food transportation emissions), with emission reduction proportions in high UCO producers like Malaysia and Indonesia being as high as over 95%, while other countries mostly achieve reductions in the 0−20% range in this scenario. The scenario of sole CRs utilization achieves 119.1 Mt CO₂ reductions (47.0%), with China, India, Brazil, and the US contributing above half of total reductions. Approximately half of the analyzed countries attain over 50% reductions in their national emissions. The scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization achieves 135.0 Mt CO₂ reductions (53.2%), nearly half of the analyzed countries could achieve complete offset of food transportation fossil fuel demand through food system wastes-derived biofuels, achieving 70%−83% emission reductions. Under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, reductions reach 174.9 Mt CO₂ (69.0%), with only 21 countries’ food transportation fossil fuel demands being incompletely offset by food system wastes-derived biofuels, and nearly 80% of countries achieving an emission reduction proportion over 70%.

For four transportation modes, UCO-derived biofuels excel in reducing emissions from road, railway & inland waterway, while CRs-derived biofuels are more effective for marine and aviation (Table S7). As road transportation accounts for the highest fuel demand among the four modes, UCO-derived biofuels generally achieve greater overall emission reductions per unit when implementing biofuel substitution according to fuel demand shares for four modes. Under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, road transportation demonstrates global leadership in emission reduction, achieving 130.8 Mt CO₂ reductions, constituting 76.9% of total food transportation emissions mitigation. Aviation and marine transportation follow with 17.3 Mt CO₂ (9.9%) and 16.7 Mt CO₂ (9.5%) reductions respectively, while railway & inland waterway transportation, constrained by existing electrification levels of railway, contribute marginally at 6.46 Mt CO₂ (3.7%). Figure 6e shows emission reduction proportions across regions, transportation modes, and scenarios. All countries exhibit consistent, substantial road transportation reductions, particularly in the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential. Emission reductions in marine transportation are concentrated in coastal and island regions (e.g., the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia), where marine transportation contributes up to 20% of national mitigation totals. Middle Eastern countries and Russia exhibit >30% mitigation enhancement under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential compared to the scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization, indicating that elevated

Uncertainty analysis

The calculations of fossil fuel demand, biofuel production, food transportation emissions, and emission reductions are rigorously examined using Monte Carlo analysis. The yield coefficients of CRs, along with the collection coefficients of CRs and UCO, determine the utilizable amount of food system wastes. The energy conversion coefficients of UCO and CRs, combined with their biofuel conversion coefficients, critically influence the amount of biofuel production. The fuel demand shares for four transportation modes directly govern fossil fuel demand across four transportation modes, which is essential for estimating fossil fuel emissions in food transportation. Additionally, WTW emission coefficients of biofuels and fossil fuels serve as pivotal parameters for quantifying emissions and emission reductions in food transportation. These key factors have therefore been incorporated into the uncertainty analysis of calculation outcomes.

The Monte Carlo method employs triangular distributions for parameter estimation, generating 10,000 independent simulations, with results aggregated using statistical indicators. As shown in Fig. 7, road transportation exhibits a broader uncertainty range in fossil fuel demand and emission calculations compared to other transportation modes, primarily due to its higher fuel demand share. The substantially greater utilizable amount of CRs relative to UCO amplifies uncertainty in the CRs derived-biofuel production potentials. Furthermore, the uncertainty ranges of emission reductions across the four scenarios increase incrementally with rising emission reduction levels, with the scenario of sole UCO utilization demonstrating a notably smaller uncertainty range than the other three scenarios.

Research remarks

Building upon the quantified global analysis of fossil fuel demand and emissions in food transportation across multiple countries, this study pioneers an internal recycling loop framework of food system. The study proposes converting food system wastes (UCO and CRs) into biofuels for food transportation, establishing a synchronized decarbonization pathway that simultaneously achieves waste valorization and dual-system (food-transportation) emission mitigation. This study reveals that most countries could completely satisfy their food transportation fuel demands while mitigating 174.9 Mt CO2 emission reductions (around 70%) by utilizing all available UCO and <20% of total CRs. The details of the research remarks are as follows.

Food transportation represents a critical intersection between food system and the transportation sector. The calculations of this study, when compared with the IPCC’s Sixth Assessment Report49,50,51, show that food transportation contributes 3.34% of food system emissions and 2.95% of transportation sector emissions, representing a shared source of emissions between these two systems. The results may be conservative as the emission calculations solely account for oil fuel and natural gas fuel amenable to substitution with biofuels, without considering electricity consumption in food transportation.

On this basis, this study proposes an internal recycling loop within the food system, whereby food system wastes are repurposed for food transportation applications. This approach offers dual benefits: alleviating the disposal burden and resource wasting associated with substantial food system wastes, while simultaneously reducing fossil fuel dependency in food transportation, thereby propelling food transportation decarbonization. While practical applications may see food system wastes-derived biofuels utilized across various transportation sectors rather than exclusively in food transportation, the evolving global carbon trading policies and carbon markets present opportunities for channeling energy and environmental benefits back to the food system through carbon quotas or economic incentives46,47.

Moving forward beyond previous studies conducted28,29,52, a global analysis comparing the biofuel production potentials is provided from waste streams of UCO and CRs, followed by the assessment of the extent to which these wastes-derived biofuels could meet food transportation fossil fuel demands. Building on this analysis, the potential emission reductions achievable through food system wastes-derived biofuels substitution are calculated and compared across different regions, countries, and transportation modes. This leads to the development of synchronized decarbonization strategies for both food and transportation systems. The findings aim to inform global food wastes utilization strategies, transportation emission mitigation approaches, and sustainable development of food system.

Matching food transportation fossil fuel demands with wastes-derived biofuels

This study reveals that total food transportation fossil fuel demand in 130 countries is 3.03 EJ, accounting for 3.27% of the transportation sector’s total demand. The demand patterns vary significantly across countries and transportation modes, with major food-producing and consuming countries like China, India, Brazil, and the US showing the highest demand. Road transportation dominates, reflecting its central role in food logistics. Regarding food system wastes availability and the biofuel production potential, the analysis indicates that UCO and CRs could theoretically provide 0.41 EJ and 38.77 EJ of energy respectively across 130 countries. Matching each country’s food transportation fossil fuel demand with food system waste-derived biofuels reveals that in the scenario of sole UCO utilization, UCO-derived biofuels could meet 13% of global food transportation fossil fuel demand. Countries rich in oil crops, such as Indonesia and Malaysia, could satisfy over 95% of their food transportation fossil fuel demands through UCO-derived biofuels. Under the scenario of sole CRs utilization, despite limiting availability to 7%, CRs-derived biofuels demonstrate significant potential, capable of meeting 65% of global food transportation fossil fuel demand. Except for the Middle East, Asia-Pacific, and Russia, most regions could satisfy over 50% of their fossil fuel demands, highlighting CRs’ substantial potential. The scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization improves satisfaction rates of fossil fuel demand, meeting 72% of the global demand by leveraging UCO’s superior energy conversion efficiency and CRs’ yield advantages. Under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, most regions could achieve complete coverage of their food transportation fossil fuel demands, demonstrating the theoretical feasibility of food transport energy self-sufficiency within food systems.

Strategizing food transportation emission reductions through wastes-derived biofuels

Across the 130 studied countries, gradient emission reductions of 289, 1203, 1361, and 17490 thousand tonnes of CO2 are achievable under four scenarios, respectively. Road transportation fuel substitution contributes the majority of emission reductions across countries, particularly in those dominated by inland transportation such as the United States, China, and Russia. European and Asia-Pacific regions show greater advantages in marine and aviation transportation emission reductions. Railway emissions reduction potential through biofuel substitution is relatively lower due to increasing electrification. From the perspective of emission reduction from unit biofuel, consistent with existing technologies-focused research23,24,53,54,55, CRs-derived biofuels demonstrate superior performance in marine and aviation applications, while UCO-derived biofuels show advantages in road, railway & inland waterway applications. Ideally, countries should prioritize deploying CRs-derived biofuels in marine and aviation transportation while reserving limited UCO resources for road transportation.

However, considering practical availability, UCO collection systems are more developed and cost-effective than those for CRs. Technically, UCO-derived biofuels production processes like HEFA offer lower cost and higher energy conversion efficiency compared with CRs conversion technologies such as Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and pyrolysis. This study assumes domestic production and use of wastes-derived biofuels without considering their import and export. However, policy-wise initiatives like the RED II (Renewable Energy Recast)‘s double-counting mechanism for UCO-derived biodiesel in EU, China’s 13% VAT (value added tax) refund on UCO exports, and the United States Biodiesel Tax Credit may foster more stable international supply chains for UCO-derived biofuels in the future. For CRs, due to higher transportation costs, tend toward localized subsidization (e.g. under Canada’s Clean Fuel Regulations, biofuel produced from CRs is eligible to receive a low-carbon credit of CAD 0.35 per liter56). Export restrictions in Southeast Asian countries and the EU’s CBAM (Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism) requirements further limit cross-border CRs-derived fuels circulation, leading to predominantly regional usage.

Overall, for resource-limited countries, improving market mechanisms, implementing favorable biofuel import policies, and establishing reliable supply chains is recommended. Countries with abundant resources and mature collection technologies should enhance waste collection and biofuel production capabilities, particularly in China and the United States, where UCO collection and conversion technologies are advanced. These countries should focus on reducing CRs-derived biofuel production costs and enhancing their competitiveness to reduce market dependence on UCO-derived biofuels. Developing countries rich in resources but technically less advanced, such as Southeast Asian and South American countries, should prioritize improving waste collection systems and exporting feedstock to countries with mature biofuel production capabilities, leveraging their own resource advantages. Countries lacking both resources and technologies should promote international cooperation, introduce small-scale biofuel production facilities, and initially focus on local short-distance food transportation to improve local energy self-sufficiency.

From the global food system perspective, the evolution of global carbon trading market mechanisms has facilitated viable pathways for channeling transportation-related emission reduction benefits back into food systems, thereby enhancing the operational feasibility of circular economy approaches. Policymakers should refine and calibrate carbon trading mechanisms pertaining to food system wastes to achieve seamless integration of biofuel emission reduction benefits into food system cycles. Key initiatives include cross-sector offset mechanisms, allocating carbon credits to feedstock providers, and implementing carbon taxes on high-emission food transportation. These measures optimize resource allocation, prevent emission reduction benefits’ concentration, and strengthen global food system resilience. The strategic utilization of carbon markets to achieve internal recycling loop within food system aims to elevate biofuels beyond mere transportation decarbonization tools to become pivotal leverage points in strengthening global food system sustainability, to advance food systems toward an integrated paradigm of sustainable development that harmonizes climate action, food security, and equity.

Limitations and future research perspectives

This study has the following limitations and uncertainties. First, the availability of food system wastes is calculated theoretically by using residual coefficient and collection coefficient according to the type of wastes, without accounting for impacts of national variations in dietary habits and technological capabilities. Second, the allocation of food system wastes for biofuel production in food transportation relies on assumed scenarios, which is a discussion on the possibility of internal loop in food system rather than reflecting real-world application conditions. Third, when modeling fossil fuel substitution by biofuels, in order to reflect the impact of the uniform penetration of biofuels under the existing transportation structure, this study assumes that UCO and CRs prepare biofuels for each transportation mode according to the existing food transportation fuel demand shares. In practical applications, better emission reduction effects may be achieved through the optimization of fuel alternatives (such as priority in the aviation field).

In addition, several problems warrant investigation in future research endeavors. This study has primarily focused on two major pathways for biofuel production from food system wastes. However, additional waste streams within the food system, including kitchen waste and livestock manure, possess potential for conversion into biofuels through various processing technologies serving as additional substitutes for fossil fuels. The expansion of feedstock diversity in biofuel production from food system waste streams could potentially yield enhanced emission reduction outcomes in food transportation applications. Furthermore, a more precise confirmation of the actual utilization of diverse food system wastes will enhance the accuracy of energy supply and emission reduction calculations.

Methodological framework

To quantify the energy and emission reduction benefits of using food system wastes-derived biofuels within food transportation, this study establishes an internal loop within the food system, identifying the primary feedstocks for biofuel production as UCO and CRs generated from agricultural production, food processing and transformation, and food consumption. CRs’ availability is calculated based on crop production data from the FAO database, combined with yield coefficients and collection coefficients of CRs from existing studies (Table S3). UCO’s availability is estimated using edible vegetable oil consumption data derived from the FAO database and region-specific statistics on UCO collection (Table S4).

After determining the maximum availability of CRs and UCO, their total energy potentials are calculated using crop-specific energy conversion coefficients for CRs from existing literature and the lower heating value for UCO from the GREET database (Table S3, Table S4). Then the GREET model is employed to account for the maximum amount of biofuel that can be produced by CRs and UCO (Table S5). Four scenarios are then constructed (see details in the following “Assumptions and scenario settings”), representing different waste utilization levels, to compare the biofuel production potentials with food transportation fossil fuel demands across countries.

For emission reduction analysis, a life cycle approach is adopted using the GREET model to evaluate the WTW emissions of biofuels and the fossil fuels they replace across different transport modes. Based on the fuel demand share for each transportation mode in different countries, the available biofuels under each scenario are proportionally allocated to each transportation mode. This allowed for an assessment of the emission reduction potential achievable by each country under varying food transportation structures.

Fossil fuel demand of food transportation

This study categorizes transportation into four distinct modes: road transportation, railway & inland waterway transportation, marine transportation, and aviation transportation, incorporating the demand for conventional fossil fuels including oil and natural gas. The fossil fuel demand of food transportation in each country can be expressed as:

$$\begin{array}{c}E{D}_{i}=({\sum }_{j}E{D}_{O,i}\times {T}_{j,i}+E{D}_{N,i})\times {F}_{i}\end{array}$$

(1)

Equation (1) represents the total food transportation fuel demand in each country by adding up the demand for various types of fuels under different transportation modes, which is used for comparative analysis with the biofuel production potential. EDi represents the fossil fuel demand (PJ) of food transportation in country i. EDO,i and EDN,i denote the demand for oil fuel and natural gas fuel, respectively. The study assumes that all natural gas fuel demand originates from road transportation57,58, with the proportion for oil fuel demand estimated according to regional consumption patterns of various fuel types globally48. Tj,i represents the proportion of oil fuel demand in transportation mode j (road, railway & inland waterway, marine, aviation). Fi denotes the proportion of food transportation relative to total transportation (Table S1), calculated based on the ratio of the transportation sector’s output allocated to the global food sector to the gross output of the transportation sector in each country, derived from the EORA26 MRIO table59,60.

Energy potential of food system waste

In this study, the CRs from 34 kinds of crop species and the UCO from 13 kinds of edible oils are considered (Table S2). The energy potentials of CRs and UCO in various countries are calculated according to crop production and consumption of edible oil, combined with waste collection coefficients and energy conversion coefficients (Table S3, Table S4).

(1)

Collectable amount and energy potential of CRs

$${C}_{{CRs},i}={\sum }_{c}{Y}_{i,c}\times \left({S}_{F,c}+{S}_{P,c}\right)\times {\lambda }_{c}$$

(2)

$${{ENE}}_{{CRs},i}={\sum }_{c}{Y}_{i,c}\times \left({S}_{F,c}+{S}_{P,c}\right)\times {\lambda }_{c}\times {p}_{{CRs},c}$$

(3)

Equation (2) calculates the total amount of CRs that can be collected in various countries based on yield coefficients and collection coefficients of CRs. On this basis, Eq. (3) calculates the energy potential of CRs by adding the energy conversion coefficients of various CRs types, which is used to calculate the production potentials of CRs-derived biofuels in various scenarios. \({C}_{{CRs},i}\) and \({{ENE}}_{{CRs},i}\) respectively represent the collectable amount (t) and theoretical energy potential (PJ) of CRs. \({Y}_{i,c}\) is the yield (t) of crop species c. \({S}_{F,c}\) and \({S}_{P,c}\) are the yield coefficients of field residues and processing residues per unit dry weight of crops, respectively (t t-1). \({\lambda }_{c}\) represents the collection coefficient61,62. \({p}_{{CRs},c}\) represents the energy conversion coefficient per unit dry weight of CRs (PJ t-1)29.

(2)

Collectable amount and energy potential of UCO

$${C}_{UCO,i}={\sum }_{u}({P}_{i,u}+I{O}_{i,u}-E{O}_{i,u})\times \lambda_{i}$$

(4)

$$\begin{array}{c}EN{E}_{UCO,i}={C}_{UCO,i}\times {p}_{UCO}\end{array}$$

(5)

Equation (4) calculates the total amount of UCO that can be collected in various countries using the UCO collection coefficient based on the production, import, and export of various vegetable edible oil. Equation (5) calculates the energy potential of UCO, which is used to calculate the production potentials of UCO-derived biofuels in various scenarios. \({C}_{{UCO},i}\) and \({{ENE}}_{{UCO},i}\) respectively represent the collectable amount (t) and theoretical energy potential (PJ) of UCO. \({P}_{i,u}\), \({{IO}}_{i,u}\), and \({{EO}}_{i,u}\) are the production, import, and export amounts (t) of edible oil type u. \({\lambda }_{i}\) represents the collection coefficient of UCO, estimated based on the consumption and collection data of UCO in each country63. \({p}_{{UCO}}\) is the lower heating value of UCO (PJ t-1).

Life cycle analysis of biofuels and fossil fuels

This study compares life cycle emissions between conventional fossil fuels and representative biofuels across multiple transportation modes through defined substitution pathways: (1) Second-generation renewable biodiesel (RD II) displaces low-sulfur diesel in road transportation and conventional diesel in railway & inland waterway64,65; (2) the second-generation marine renewable biodiesel (RD II marine) substitutes heavy fuel oil in marine transport55,66; (3) the biomass Fischer-Tropsch aviation fuel (FT-AF) and HEFA sustainable aviation fuel (HEFA-SAF) replace conventional aviation fuel54,67; (4) the biomass liquefied natural gas (bio-LNG) supplants fossil-based liquefied natural gas (LNG) in road transport68. Figure 8 illustrates the WTW system boundaries encompassing biofuel production, distribution, and end-use combustion. The analysis evaluates emissions across all stages, including feedstock collection, conversion processes, transportation logistics, and final energy utilization.

This study evaluates biofuel production pathways through distinct biofuel conversion technologies. Fast pyrolysis converts CRs into RD II, while esterification-hydrogenation processes UCO into RD-II. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA) methods produce FT-AF and HEFA-SAF from CRs and UCO, respectively. Anaerobic digestion processes both feedstocks into bio-LNG69,70,71,72. The analysis employs Argonne National Laboratory’s GREET model to quantify fuel production efficiencies and emission intensities across full lifecycle boundaries: well-to-wheel (WTW) for road/rail fuels, well-to-haul (WTH) for marine fuels, and well-to-wake (WTWa) for aviation fuels. The model calculation results of biofuel conversion efficiencies and emissions from biofuels/fossil fuels as shown in Table S5, Fig. S1. As only two energy sources (oil fuel and natural gas fuel) suitable to be substituted by biofuels are included in the emission analysis, the estimated overall emissions from food transportation in this study may be conservative. Detailed emission accounting methodologies and system boundaries of biofuels and fossil fuels are provided in Supplementary Information (Supplementary Methods Section 5).

Assumptions and scenario settings

To analyze the energy and emission reduction contributions of reusing food system wastes in food transportation under varying utilization levels, this study defines four scenarios of food system waste utilization: Scenario of sole UCO utilization, Scenario of sole CRs utilization, Scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization, and Scenario of maximum biofuel production potential. The assumptions for each scenario are as follows:

Scenario of sole UCO utilization: Given that biofuel production from UCO has been already widely applied and UCO has a large presence in international markets, with biofuel production being its primary end use, this scenario assumes that all available UCO is converted into biofuels and reused within food transportation. The purpose is to assess the sole contribution of UCO reuse to food system.

Scenario of sole CRs utilization: While biofuel production from CRs is less common compared to UCO due to higher feedstock transport costs and broader competition from other uses, CRs generally have a higher yield potential. In this scenario, based on the IEA statistics on the proportion of global bioenergy used in the transport sector73,74, it is assumed that only 7% of CRs are utilized for biofuel production and reused in food transportation. This reflects the potential contribution of CRs to the food system under competing use constraints.

Scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization: Considering that UCO-derived biofuels are more mature and typically have fewer competing applications, this scenario assumes that UCO-derived biofuels are used first to substitute fossil fuels. Any remaining fuel demand is supplemented by CRs-derived biofuels. To reflect the competition for CRs in other applications, their availability remains capped at 7%.

Scenario of maximum biofuel production potential: This scenario adopts the same utilization pathways as the co-utilization scenario but removes the 7% cap on CRs utilization. It represents the ideal case where food system wastes are fully leveraged to realize their maximum potential for fuel substitution and emission reduction in food transportation.

In addition to these scenario settings, this study assumes that, under each scenario, the biofuels derived from UCO and CRs are allocated to each transportation mode in proportion to the country-specific fossil fuel demand shares across transportation modes. This approach reflects the benefits of biofuel penetration into all food transportation modes while maintaining the current national food transportation structures.

Calculations of emission reductions

Calculations of biofuel production and emission reductions for each scenario proceed as follows:

(1)

Scenario of sole UCO utilization

Under the scenario of sole UCO utilization, it is assumed that all UCO in various countries is used for biofuel production. The total production of UCO-derived biofuels under sole UCO utilization (\({{ENE}}_{1,i}\)) (PJ) is calculated as:

$$\begin{array}{c}EN{E}_{1,i}=min \left(EN{E}_{UCO,i}^{{\prime}},E{D}_{i}\right)\end{array}$$

(6)

$$\begin{array}{c}EN{E}_{UCO,i}^{\prime}=EN{E}_{UCO,i}\times {\rho }_{UCO,i}\end{array}$$

(7)

$$\begin{array}{c}{\rho }_{UCO,i}=\left[{\sum }_{j}\left({T}_{j,i}\times {\rho }_{UCO,O,j}\right)\times E{D}_{O,i}+{\rho }_{UCO,N}\times E{D}_{N,i}\right]/E{D}_{i}\end{array}$$

(8)

Equation (8) calculates the conversion efficiency of UCO to biofuels by countries, which is used to convert the energy potential of UCO into biofuel production potential. Equations (6) and (7) respectively represent the maximum production potential and the utilization of UCO-derived biofuels under this scenario. The emission reduction contributed by UCO-derived biofuels (\({{ER}}_{1,i}\)) as substitutes for fossil fuels in food transportation is calculated as:

$$E{R}_{1,i}={\sum }_{f,j}\left[{T}_{f,j,i}\times \left({E}_{con,f,j}-{E}_{UCO,f,j}\right)\right]\times EN{E}_{1,i}$$

(9)

Equation (9) allocates the biofuel production potential s under this scenario according to the food transportation fuel demand shares, and calculates the emission reductions in various countries under this scenario by combining the difference between fossil fuel and biofuel emissions per unit under each transportation mode. \({{ENE}}_{{UCO},i}^{{\prime} }\) is the maximum biofuel production for UCO (PJ). \({\rho }_{{UCO},i}\) is the average conversion efficiency of UCO-derived biofuels. \({\rho }_{{UCO},O,j}\) and \({\rho }_{{UCO},N}\) are the UCO-derived biofuel conversion efficiencies for oil fuel and natural gas fuel, respectively. \({E}_{{con},f,j}\) is the life cycle emission (kg PJ-1) for conventional fuels of type f (oil fuel or natural gas fuel). \({E}_{{UCO},f,j}\) is the life cycle emission (kg PJ-1) for UCO-derived biofuels of type f under unit energy consumption.

(2)

Scenario of sole CRs utilization

To approximate realistic CRs availability for biofuel production, under this scenario, this study refers to the statistics of world’s bioenergy available for transportation fuel supply obtained from IEA73 and IRENA74, assuming available CRs for biofuel production not to exceed 7% of CRs’ total energy potential.

The total production of CRs-derived biofuels under sole CRs utilization (\({{ENE}}_{2,i}\)) (PJ) is calculated as:

$$EN{E}_{2,i}=min \left(\gamma \times EN{E}_{CRs,i}^{\prime},E{D}_{i}\right)$$

(10)

$$EN{E}_{CRs,i}^{\prime}=EN{E}_{CRs,i}\times {\rho }_{CRs,i}$$

(11)

$${\rho }_{CRs,i}=\left[{\sum }_{j}\left({T}_{j,i}\times {\rho }_{CRs,O,j}\right)\times E{D}_{O,i}+{\rho }_{CRs,N}\times E{D}_{N,i}\right]/E{D}_{i}$$

(12)

Equation (12) calculates the conversion efficiency of CRs to biofuels by countries, which is used to convert the energy potential of CRs into biofuel production potential. Equations (10) and (11) respectively represent the maximum production potential and the utilization of CRs-derived biofuels under this scenario. The emission reduction contributed by CRs-derived biofuels (\({{ER}}_{2,i}\)) as substitutions for fossil fuels in food transportation is calculated as:

$$E{R}_{2,i}={\sum }_{f,j}[{T}_{f,j,i}\times ({E}_{con,f,j}-{E}_{CRs,f,j})]\times EN{E}_{2,i}$$

(13)

Equation (13) conforms to the principle of Eq. (9). \({{ENE}}_{{CRs},i}^{{\prime} }\) is the maximum biofuel production for CRs (PJ). \(\gamma\) is the proportion of CRs that can be used to produce biofuels in the total (assumed as 7%). \({\rho }_{{CRs},i}\) is the average conversion efficiency of CRs-derived biofuel. \({\rho }_{{CRs},O,j}\) and \({\rho }_{{CRs},N}\) are the CRs-derived biofuel conversion efficiencies for oil fuel and natural gas fuel, respectively. \({E}_{{CRs},f,j}\) is the life cycle emission for CRs-derived biofuels of type f under unit energy consumption.

(3)

Scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization.

The total production of food system wastes-derived biofuels under UCO and CRs co-utilization (\({{ENE}}_{3,i}\)) is calculated as:

$$EN{E}_{3,i}=min\,(EN{E}_{UCO,i}^{\prime}+\gamma \times EN{E}_{CRs,i}^{\prime},E{D}_{i})$$

(14)

$$EN{E}_{3,CRs,i}=EN{E}_{3,i}-EN{E}_{1,i}$$

(15)

Equations (14) and (15) respectively represent the total utilization of biofuels and the utilization of CRs-derived biofuels in this scenario. The emission reduction contributed jointly by UCO- and CRs-derived biofuels (\({{ER}}_{3,i}\)) is calculated by Eqs. (16)–(18):

$$E{R}_{3,i}=E{R}_{3,UCO,i}+E{R}_{3,CRS,i}$$

(16)

$$E{R}_{3,UCO,i}={\sum }_{f,j}[{T}_{f,j,i}\times ({E}_{con,fj}-{E}_{UCO,f,j})]\times EN{E}_{1,i}$$

(17)

$$E{R}_{3,CRS,i}={\sum }_{f,j}[{T}_{f,j,i}\times ({E}_{con,fj}-{E}_{CRs,f,j})]\times EN{E}_{3,CRs,i}$$

(18)

where, \({{ENE}}_{3,{CRs},i}\) is the production (PJ) of CRs-derived biofuels under this scenario. \({{ER}}_{3,{UCO},i}\) and \({{ER}}_{3,{CRS},i}\) are the emission reductions (t CO2) for UCO- and CRs-derived biofuels, respectively.

(4)

Scenario of maximum biofuel production potential

The total production of food system wastes-derived biofuels under UCO and CRs co-utilization without considering CRs’ competing uses (\({{ENE}}_{4,i}\)) is calculated as:

$$EN{E}_{4,i}=min(EN{E}_{UCO,i}^{\prime}+EN{E}_{CRs,i}^{\prime},E{D}_{i})$$

(19)

$$EN{E}_{4,CRs,i}=EN{E}_{4,i}-EN{E}_{1,i}$$

(20)

Equations (19) and (20) respectively represent the total utilization of biofuels and the utilization of CRs-derived biofuels in this scenario. The emission reduction contributed jointly by UCO- and CRs-derived biofuels (\({{ER}}_{4,i}\)) is calculated by Eqs. (21)-(23):

$$E{R}_{4,i}=E{R}_{4,UCO,i}+E{R}_{4,CRS,i}$$

(21)

$$E{R}_{4,UCO,i}={\sum }_{f,j}[{T}_{f,j}\times ({E}_{con,f,j}-{E}_{UCO,f,j})]\times EN{E}_{1,i}$$

(22)

$$E{R}_{4,CRS,i}={\sum }_{f,j}[{T}_{f,j}\times ({E}_{con,f,j}-{E}_{CRs,f,j})]\times EN{E}_{4,CRs,i}$$

(23)

where, \({{ENE}}_{4,{CRs},i}\) is the production (PJ) of CRs-derived biofuels under this scenario. \({{ER}}_{4,{UCO},i}\) and \({{ER}}_{4,{CRS},i}\) are the emission reductions (t CO2) of UCO- and CRs-derived biofuels, respectively.

Data sources

The study encompasses 130 countries globally, with 2021 as the target year. The fossil fuel demand data for the transportation sector are sourced from the IEA World Energy Statistics and Balances database73. The food transportation fuel demand shares are calculated using the 2019 EORA26 MRIO Tables59,60. The fuel consumption data are obtained from OPEC’s 2021 regional fuel consumption statistics48. Country-specific crop yields and edible oil production, import, and export data are sourced from the FAOSTAT database75. CRs’ yield coefficients, collection coefficients, and energy conversion coefficients, along with UCO’s collection coefficients, are derived from meta-analyses of existing studies61,62,63. The lower heating values of UCO and aviation fuel and operational parameters for various carriers are obtained from the GREET model database69,76,77,78,79, with WTP process emissions calculated using the GREET model.

Reporting summary

Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.

title: EU and UAE host high-level session to advance sustainable aviation fuels
description:
The European Union and the UAE jointly convened a high-level session on sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) during the Dubai Airshow 2025 Sustainability Program, underscoring growing global momentum for coordinated action to decarbonize the aviation industry.
Emirates, ENOC sign MoU to advance sustainable aviation fuel supply in Dubai Aligning global strategies for net-zero aviation Participants explored ways to fast-track the deployment of SAF, widely viewed as the most immediate and scalable solution for reducing aviation emissions.
Lucie Berger, Ambassador of the European Union to the UAE, stated: “The European Union and the UAE share a common ambition to lead global efforts in sustainable aviation.
By working together, we can unlock innovation, scale up clean fuel production, and create the partnerships needed to achieve climate neutrality.” Saif Ghubash, assistant under-secretary for the Petroleum, Gas, and Mineral Resources Sector at the MoEI, said: “Sustainable aviation fuels are essential to achieving our national net-zero goals.
The initiative aims to help advance common net-zero objectives while contributing to a more resilient and diversified global energy transition.
text:
The European Union and the UAE jointly convened a high-level session on sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) during the Dubai Airshow 2025 Sustainability Program, underscoring growing global momentum for coordinated action to decarbonize the aviation industry.

Organized by the Delegation of the European Union to the UAE as part of the EU Green Diplomacy Weeks initiative in collaboration with the UAE Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure (MoEI) and the EU-funded EU-GCC Cooperation on Green Transition Project, the session gathered senior policymakers, industry leaders, and key stakeholders to discuss accelerating SAF production, implementing enabling policies, and deepening international partnerships.

Emirates, ENOC sign MoU to advance sustainable aviation fuel supply in Dubai

Aligning global strategies for net-zero aviation

Participants explored ways to fast-track the deployment of SAF, widely viewed as the most immediate and scalable solution for reducing aviation emissions. Discussions highlighted strong policy alignment between:

The EU’s RefuelEU Aviation Regulation, which mandates a minimum 2 percent SAF blend by 2025, rising to 70 percent by 2050

The UAE’s Net Zero by 2050 Strategic Initiative and National Hydrogen Strategy, which prioritize clean and alternative fuels within a diversified energy mix

The ICAO global aspirational goal to cut carbon emissions in international aviation by 5 percent by 2030 through the use of SAF.

Speakers noted that shared policy frameworks and coordinated investments are essential to scaling supply chains, reducing the cost of SAF, and enabling airlines and airports to transition toward low-carbon operations.

Lucie Berger, Ambassador of the European Union to the UAE, stated: “The European Union and the UAE share a common ambition to lead global efforts in sustainable aviation. By working together, we can unlock innovation, scale up clean fuel production, and create the partnerships needed to achieve climate neutrality.”

Saif Ghubash, assistant under-secretary for the Petroleum, Gas, and Mineral Resources Sector at the MoEI, said: “Sustainable aviation fuels are essential to achieving our national net-zero goals. Through collaboration with the EU, we aim to accelerate local production, strengthen supply chains, and advance policies that support a greener aviation future.”

Strengthening cross-regional cooperation

The session forms part of the broader work carried out under the EU-GCC Cooperation on Green Transition Project, which supports partnerships across the Gulf region on energy, climate action, and sustainable finance.

The initiative aims to help advance common net-zero objectives while contributing to a more resilient and diversified global energy transition.

title: US generated more renewable blending credits in October than September
description:
The U.S. saw an increase in renewable blending credits in October compared with September, according to data released Thursday by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), reported Reuters.
Ethanol (D6) blending credits reached approximately 1.28 billion in October, up from around 1.23 billion in September.
Meanwhile, biodiesel (D4) blending credits rose to 665 million in October, up from 660 million the previous month.
These credits are used by oil refiners and importers to demonstrate compliance with EPA-mandated renewable blending requirements for petroleum-based fuels.
They are issued for every gallon of biofuel produced.
text:
The U.S. saw an increase in renewable blending credits in October compared with September, according to data released Thursday by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), reported Reuters.

Ethanol (D6) blending credits reached approximately 1.28 billion in October, up from around 1.23 billion in September. Meanwhile, biodiesel (D4) blending credits rose to 665 million in October, up from 660 million the previous month.

These credits are used by oil refiners and importers to demonstrate compliance with EPA-mandated renewable blending requirements for petroleum-based fuels. They are issued for every gallon of biofuel produced.

title: Global council expects platinum demand from sustainable aviation fuel to increase incrementally
description:
The council expects yearly SAF capacity additions to increase eight-fold from about two-million tonnes in 2024 to about 16-million tonnes by 2050, while platinum demand from SAF production is expected to increase from negligible volumes to about 260 00 oz/y by 2050.
“This platinum demand growth will be incremental overall, mitigating the expected decrease in petroleum platinum demand as global markets continue to make their energy transition from 2030 to 2050,” the council explains.
In the FT SAF production pathway, solid materials such as biomass are first converted into synthetic gas (syngas).
This makes it a strong candidate for commercial-scale SAF production, although supportive policies and regulatory frameworks are needed to accelerate its deployment.
However, cobalt catalysts are preferred in PtL FT and these use platinum as a promoter.
text:
Platinum is required across all major sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production pathways, including power-to liquid (PtL), which uses the Fischer Tropsch process (FT), as well as the FT process itself, and while current platinum demand from SAF is modest, it is expected to grow significantly in the long term, industry body the World Platinum Investment Council points out.

The council expects yearly SAF capacity additions to increase eight-fold from about two-million tonnes in 2024 to about 16-million tonnes by 2050, while platinum demand from SAF production is expected to increase from negligible volumes to about 260 00 oz/y by 2050.

“This platinum demand growth will be incremental overall, mitigating the expected decrease in petroleum platinum demand as global markets continue to make their energy transition from 2030 to 2050,” the council explains.

The International Air Transport Association estimates that SAF could contribute about 65% of the reduction in emissions needed by aviation to reach net-zero emissions by 2050.

Unlike petroleum-based kerosene, SAF is produced from sustainable, non-petroleum feedstocks such as waste oils, agricultural residues and municipal solid waste, or via synthetic e-fuels combining renewable electricity with captured CO₂, the council explains.

Originally developed by German chemists Franz Fischer and Hans Tropsch, this year marks 100 years since the FT process was developed.

Their research demonstrated that a mixture of the gases carbon monoxide and hydrogen could be transformed over suitable catalysts into liquid and solid hydrocarbons. Today, FT is used in myriad industrial applications, the council outlines.

PtL is a synthetic jet fuel produced using renewable electricity, with water and CO₂ serving as the primary inputs.

To create a climate-neutral carbon feedstock, green hydrogen and captured CO₂ (from the atmosphere or industrial sources) are used.

These components are then combined through FT synthesis to form liquid hydrocarbons, which are subsequently refined into a kerosene-equivalent fuel, the council adds.

In the FT SAF production pathway, solid materials such as biomass are first converted into synthetic gas (syngas). This syngas is then processed through FT synthesis into liquid wax. FT has significant scalability potential for SAF production as it can use a range of feedstocks, including waste materials that would otherwise be discarded.

This makes it a strong candidate for commercial-scale SAF production, although supportive policies and regulatory frameworks are needed to accelerate its deployment.

PLATINUM’S ROLE

The council highlights that platinum plays an important supporting role in certain types of FT synthesis. Iron catalysts dominate biomass FT and do not use platinum.

However, cobalt catalysts are preferred in PtL FT and these use platinum as a promoter. Even at very low concentrations, platinum improves cobalt catalyst reduction, stability and dispersion, resulting in higher efficiency and longer lifetimes, the council posits.

It adds that platinum has a significant role in isomerisation, which is needed in both the FT and the PtL FT SAF production pathways, where it functions as a catalyst to transform straight-chain hydrocarbons into branched isomers with better cold-flow properties.

“Without this step, SAF would fail to meet the strict freezing point requirements necessary for safe, high-altitude flight,” the council avers.

title: Masdar and Tadweer team up on waste-to-SAF project in Abu Dhabi - gasworld
authors: gasworld, Dominic Ellis, Molly Burgess, www.gasworld.com, dominic-ellis
description:
UAE clean energy major Masdar and waste management firm Tadweer Group are teaming up to develop what they claim will be the first commercial-scale waste-to-sustainable aviation fuel [SAF] project in Abu Dhabi.
Mohamed Jameel Al Ramahi, CEO at Masdar, said the project will advance the UAE’s profile in sustainable aviation, supporting the growth of a sector critical to the nation’s economic development, while driving its decarbonisation.
Ali Al Dhaheri, Managing Director and CEO of Tadweer, said it aims to showcase the “incredible potential of waste” and set a benchmark for sustainable transformation worldwide.
Energy company Phillips 66 has signed a contract to supply global logistics company DHL Express with 240,000 tonnes of sustainable aviation fuel from its Rodeo renewable energy complex in California.
Houston-based Syzygy Plasmonics and Honeywell UOP claimed they have cracked the cost and feedstock challenges that have so far held back SAF scaling.
text:
UAE clean energy major Masdar and waste management firm Tadweer Group are teaming up to develop what they claim will be the first commercial-scale waste-to-sustainable aviation fuel [SAF] project in Abu Dhabi.

The plant will covert around 500,000 tonnes of waste into SAF per year, using a hybrid production pathway that combines renewable energy-powered electrolysis producing green hydrogen and waste gasification turning syngas into SAF through various proven chemical processes.

Mohamed Jameel Al Ramahi, CEO at Masdar, said the project will advance the UAE’s profile in sustainable aviation, supporting the growth of a sector critical to the nation’s economic development, while driving its decarbonisation.

Ali Al Dhaheri, Managing Director and CEO of Tadweer, said it aims to showcase the “incredible potential of waste” and set a benchmark for sustainable transformation worldwide.

Once operational, the project is expected to serve multiple markets, positioning Abu Dhabi as a regional hub for SAF and supporting the decarbonisation of a sector that accounted for over 18% of the UAE’s GDP in 2023, according to IATA data.

SAF has the potential to reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 80% compared with conventional jet fuel, according to IATA estimates, but scaling hinges on competitive pricing.

A recent report from PA Consulting found producers need to agree ‘creative solutions with buyers’ that keep costs low while assuring a minimum return.

But through government mandates and wide range of corporate partnerships, the market is gaining momentum.

Energy company Phillips 66 has signed a contract to supply global logistics company DHL Express with 240,000 tonnes of sustainable aviation fuel from its Rodeo renewable energy complex in California.

Houston-based Syzygy Plasmonics and Honeywell UOP claimed they have cracked the cost and feedstock challenges that have so far held back SAF scaling.

A technology developed by California-based Universal Fuel Technologies (Unifuel) that upgrades renewable feedstocks into SAF has advanced through the initial qualification process which will support the fuel’s entry to commercial aviation markets.

title: Sinopec Technologies Featured in Green Innovation Cases

text:
Green Technology Innovation Cases

The China Patent Protection Association recently announced the "2025 Annual Green Technology Innovation Cases," selecting 60 cases that showcase advancements in green technology. These cases highlight significant developments in sustainable and low-carbon technologies.

Key Technological Developments

Among the selected cases are key technologies for producing sustainable bio-aviation fuel, developed by the Petrochemical Research Institute. title: Allied Biofuels and Praj to build ethanol refinery in Uzbekistan
description:
Allied Biofuels and Praj Industries have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop Central Asia’s largest ethanol production facility in the Khorezm region of Uzbekistan.
Praj’s Technology for Ethanol Refinery will generate 890 tonnes per day (or 293,700 tonnes per annum) of 95% ethanol and capture biogenic CO2 from the 1G process.
The project represents the crucial first step in establishing Central Asia’s first integrated refinery producing SAF, Electro-Synthetic SAF (e-SAF), and green diesel.
Under the agreement, Praj will deploy its proven first-generation ethanol technology, supply proprietary equipment, and provide design, engineering, procurement, and commissioning support.
Sorghum will be used as the primary feedstock for ethanol production, which will in turn serve as the base input for advanced conversion technologies to produce sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel.
text:
Allied Biofuels and Praj Industries have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop Central Asia’s largest ethanol production facility in the Khorezm region of Uzbekistan.

Praj’s Technology for Ethanol Refinery will generate 890 tonnes per day (or 293,700 tonnes per annum) of 95% ethanol and capture biogenic CO2 from the 1G process.

The Allied Biofuels project will utilise Ethanol from the 1G process to produce 160,400 tonnes per annum of sustainable aviation fuel and 5,040 tonnes per annum of green diesel, whereas biogenic CO2 from the 1G process will combine together with the Synthesis Gas from Gasification process and Green Hydrogen made from 2,000 Mega Watt of PEM Electrolysers to produce annually 257,000 tonnes of Electro-Sustainable Aviation Fuel (e-SAF).

The project represents the crucial first step in establishing Central Asia’s first integrated refinery producing SAF, Electro-Synthetic SAF (e-SAF), and green diesel.

Under the agreement, Praj will deploy its proven first-generation ethanol technology, supply proprietary equipment, and provide design, engineering, procurement, and commissioning support.

Sorghum will be used as the primary feedstock for ethanol production, which will in turn serve as the base input for advanced conversion technologies to produce sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel.

The project is designed to align with Uzbekistan’s climate strategy and directly support the work of the country’s Net Zero Emissions Office, which is driving national policies toward carbon neutrality. By enabling large-scale ethanol-to-SAF conversion, the refinery will help displace fossil-based aviation fuels, reduce greenhouse-gas emissions, and advance Uzbekistan’s role as a regional leader in renewable energy.
